content.body:
WS was built by the community and then privatised. It still exists but has changed very much since the Foundation with a new Board was created. 

I was one of the contributors volunteers to WS Android app when new payed app was released and our API key was revoked access to the server. You can read more in the message we updated the app with: https://warmshowers.bike (it has a short background story).

Michal was one of the main developers of Trustroots.org. We are also in contact with BeWelcome.org team. 

In general hospitality exchange communities face issues with governance one by one. Probably the most spectacular was CouchSurfing.org becoming CouchSurfing.com.

We can maybe tell more at the next meeting.
I don't exclude collaborating with WS in the future though, if they were open to that.

> <@danielbakas:matrix.org> sent a file.

The proposal sounds very executively üòé. I am personally not very good at following the paths, and especially the perspective of being measured in any way makes me feel rather uncomfortable, but it's probably more a different operations mode then anything else, not necessarily incompatible with yours (hopefully!). 

I have a comment to _Value Generation and Monetization Strategies_

As mentioned earlier, I was a contributor to the community built WarmShowers Android app. Out of the "users base" built with this app, WarmShowers LLC was created - on stolen intellectual property (of volunteers from the community who contributed their time, skills and ideas) and privatised community data.

With Solid we hope to bring the ownership back to the community. We'd like to build open standards that every app in the domain can integrate with and help the community grow together, in a non-competitive way.

We don't want anyone any more to take advantage of our community and extract value out of it. We'd like to cultivate sustainable community that brings value to its members outside of any businesses models and monetization strategies. 

Would this profile fit in the strategy for Solid Practitioners?

content.body:
I believe there is no search for **the** strategy. When it comes to value generation and financial (or broader economic) sustainability there is a place and need for pluralism.
What you are saying sounds really great to me. Would you be open to sharing some details on how you plan for the community that benefits from the value you generate to support your work and incorporate some form of reciprocity?
BTW some years ago I was actively participating in designing https://www.valueflo.ws/ which aims to be generic enough to describe any approach that people would like to practice. Not sure how close it currently is to that goal but if anyone is interested to try and describe their approaches I would be interested in testing it out.

content.body: I opened a PR for us just to have this list here before we decide where best to add it: https://github.com/solid-contrib/practitioners/pull/3

> Would you be open to sharing some details on how you plan for the community that benefits from the value you generate to support your work and incorporate some form of reciprocity?

Sure, it's nothing particularly special, just being transparent about the costs. We got founding from nlNet earlier and plan to apply again soon. With that we should probably establish some "salaries" or hourly-rate for contributing and then gradually transition from external founding to community support to cover the operations. If we bring enough value for the community, it will collectively strive to cover our needs so that we keep providing the value. From WS financial reports the community has enough capacity to cover our needs with a surplus / pay us decent market rates (which are way above my needs). 
(I did not discuss it with michal/mrkvon very extensively yet)

I don't have anything specific in mind. Grants like ones from NLnet are one option, I also currently work on project arranged with them. Some people use services like https://opencollective.com/
I think we can document all kinds of approaches that different practitioners are using so that everyone can have a good picture of what is available out there.

Hi, reposting from https://matrix.to/#/#solid:converser.eu, maybe you'll appreciate this offtopic üòú

In a couple of hours, there is an important moment for **UNIX Timestamp** that we all use and love üòâ

It will reach **1.7 billion** today at **Tue Nov 14 2023 22:13:20 GMT+0000**. ü•≥üéÇüéâ

This kind of roundness only happens every 3 years or so; 2 billion will come in 2033.

You can watch it e.g. at https://www.unixtimestamp.com/ or make a script or whatnot üëÄ

See when it happens in your local time by running `new Date(1.7 * 10**12).toLocaleString()` in some JavaScript console (e.g. Node or your web browser developer tools) üôÇ

So, get ready to celebrate! üòÅ

_note, this is not exactly 1.7 billion seconds since timestamp's inception, because of [leap seconds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leap_second)_

content.body: In order for Solid to be adopted globally, I believe we should try to appeal, not only to social and moral values, which Solid is already rooted in, but also to the practical applications it can have, where the majority of businesses and organizations that could implement Solid have asked the same first question when we share Solid with them: "But how is this more valuable to me than what we currently have, specially if there is no clear way on how to make it economically sustainable, let alone profitable?"

content.body: The reason we propose that Solid Practitioners work together on defining possible _Value Generation and Monetization Strategies_, is because, that way, we can get ahead of situations like the ones mariha just shared, where individuals with questionable goals and values could try (or have succeeded in) the privatization or immoral monetization of Solid

content.body: The fundamental reason we included a _Value Generation and Monetization Strategies_ section, is because different profiles might be looking for different things in Solid. Some may be individual users looking to store their individual data elsewhere, and some might be big companies, organizations or governments with business or socioeconomic objectives that have local, regional or even a global impact

Always rooted in the values and goals of Solid we all share üòÑ
Food for thought üòã

I agree with a very broad spectrum of strategies. Personally, I would hope that all the strategies meet two simple requirements:

1. Honesty - no matter what the strategy embraces people who use it openly communicate it
2. Practice - someone at least is trying to put it into practice, even if they 'fail' it is still a valuable experience

Given the above everything could be a fair game

I just saw a headline, "You hate Youtube ads. But what's the fix?", and I thought, "Well, a decentralized protocol that let people build interoperable apps for sharing videos would be a huge step in the right direction."
And I realized that I have an experience like this every day, if not multiple times a day, where I'll either see a headline, or hear something on the radio or on a podcast, and think, "Solid would fix that." 
Another example: I've heard Cory Doctorow interviewed on several podcasts lately, and on one hand, I'm like, "Yes, exactly!" to all of the problems of platforms that he points out, but on the other hand, I'm like, "How is this guy not talking about Solid?!" It's like someone ranting about the woes of spoiled milk, and never mentioning pasteurization.
Anyway...here's why I bring it up: one of my longer-term hopes for the [Getting Started](https://solid-contrib.github.io/getting-started/) site ( [repo here](https://github.com/solid-contrib/getting-started/) ) is to create a blog, or video channel, or something like that, to post frequent content (or links to externally created content) on one theme: "Here's how Solid will fix that."
And I want to mention it here, because: 1) I'm not sure when I'll be able to get to it, and 2) I think it might be a task that would benefit from several contributors working together--some people have more expertise, and others are better at explaining things, and others at delivering messages in an inspiring way. 

I suppose, rather than just lament that the thing doesn't exist, I should say, if anyone agrees with me, then perhaps we could discuss this as part of the Solid Practitioners group (at a mtg, or here, or in the forum?), or maybe we could try to form a separate group--I'm not an expert on getting things done in groups. Feedback very much wlecome!

Another example: I've heard Cory Doctorow interviewed on several podcasts lately, and on one hand, I'm like, "Yes, exactly!" to all of the problems of platforms that he points out, but on the other hand, I'm like, "How is this guy not talking about Solid?!" It's like someone ranting about the woes of spoiled milk, and never mentioning pasteurization.
Anyway...here's why I bring it up: one of my longer-term hopes for the Getting Started site ( repo here ) is to create a blog, or video channel, or something like that, to post frequent content (or links to externally created content) on one theme: "Here's how Solid will fix that."
And I want to mention it here, because: 1) I'm not sure when I'll be able to get to it, and 2) I think it might be a task that would benefit from several contributors working together--some people have more expertise, and others are better at explaining things, and others at delivering messages in an inspiring way.

I suppose, rather than just lament that the thing doesn't exist, I should say, if anyone agrees with me, then perhaps we could discuss this as part of the Solid Practitioners group (at a mtg, or here, or in the forum?), or maybe we could try to form a separate group--I'm not an expert on getting things done in groups. Feedback very much wlecome!

content.body: A very interesting discussion btw

Well, I'd encourage you to hold your horses and wait until I do as I said I would in the meeting and post a revised README outlining the purpose, scope, and audience of the group.  Once that is online (probably tomorrow), you can all have at it and make suggestions for ammendments.  This chatroom is a good place to bring up general topics, but if we want agreement amongst the group, that has to happen on github where there is a record or what and why we decided.  In general my comment on strategies is that our business is supporting existing projects and to try to develop a strategy for the adoption of Solid is *way* beyond our resources.  It should not be our business to define strategies from above but to help projects that are solving community issues develop the strategies they need to complete their specific projects.

content.formatted_body:
@mariha wrote "With Solid we hope to bring the ownership back to the community. We'd like to build open standards that every app in the domain can integrate with and help the community grow together, in a non-competitive way.

We don't want anyone any more to take advantage of our community and extract value out of it. We'd like to cultivate sustainable community that brings value to its members outside of any businesses models and monetization strategies."

I agree. There are well-funded enterprises working on Solid in relation to business models and monetization strategies and those enterprises typically do not address the needs of public and community-based organizations. Hopefully Solid Practitioners can begin to fill the current void in that regard.

We (sleepy.bike core contributors) would like to apply for [NGI Sargasso](https://ngisargasso.eu/) grant. For that we need a transatlantic partner - an organization or SME from US or Canada to (loosely) collaborate with us.

The funding from the program is for EU entity only, there is little commitment from the transatlantic partner required, but they have to have independent resources. They need to write a letter of support for us, and we need to outline how we intend to collaborate.

We think Solid folks would be a natural fit ;)

Application deadline is December 18, 2023.

Please, let us know if you want to collaborate with us or have ideas who to ask. Thank you!

~mariha, ~michal

content.body: I'll be also happy to collaborate with someone on this, I've been trying to find the right words and terms to describe our situation for quite some time - and my understanding of Solid is still quite limited, despite having based the project on it ;)

It would be actually very helpful for the people who are considering joining our platform/community to explain well for them how is sleepy.bike different then anything they know so far, and especially why is the registration so complicated.

It's been quite long since I started the project, 3 or 4 years, and most people from old WarmShowers probably already got used to the new community-governance, some never knew the old one, or maybe they are entirely new to the reciprocal hospitality, community apps and digital commons all together! We have some backstory that supports our mission but we also already lost the momentum from within the community and the history alone may be not enough to motivate people to try something new. 

So a well prepared explanation of Solid in our use case would be very useful for us too!

**Announcement** I've created a [preliminary agenda](https://github.com/solid-contrib/practitioners/blob/main/meetings/2023-11-30.md) for the meeting, basically I suggest we spend the time introducing the projects we are each workng on, similar to what @mariha has done above.  If there are other things to add to the agenda, either submit a PR or just DM me an I'll add it.

I don't think I'll be able to attend the next meeting, but I was wondering if anyone knows a good way to do server-side pagination in a solid pod. Our app has a use case where we're trying to implement a messaging/chat system. Since there could be hundreds or thousands of messages, we can't reasonably handle all of them client-side.

Does anyone know of a good way to do server-side pagination?

* I don't think I'll be able to attend the next meeting, but I was wondering if anyone knows a good way to do server-side pagination in a solid pod. Our app has a use case where we're trying to implement a messaging/chat system. Since there could be hundreds or thousands of messages, we can't reasonably handle all of them client-side.

Does anyone know of a good way to do server-side pagination?

m.new_content.body:
I don't think I'll be able to attend the next meeting, but I was wondering if anyone knows a good way to do server-side pagination in a solid pod. Our app has a use case where we're trying to implement a messaging/chat system. Since there could be hundreds or thousands of messages, we can't reasonably handle all of them client-side.

Does anyone know of a good way to do server-side pagination?

content.body:
At the moment, I don't think there is a way. This was being discussed in this issue, but it seems like there hasn't been much activity for a while so I'm not sure about the status: https://github.com/solid/specification/issues/227#issuecomment-773945439

The best thing you can do at the moment, assuming you're talking about paginating documents, is making a request to a container and request the documents in chunks of N per page (doing N parallel requests). If what you meant is paginating triples from a single document, there is no way to do it. If you are able to decide the structure of the documents, you should write data in separated documents instead. For example, for a chat you could have one document per day instead of a document per conversation.

content.body:
Very interesting. Thanks for the link. This seems to me to put a pretty hard upper limit on the amount of data a solid app can reasonably work with. I'm not sure how well either of those workarounds will scale.

And yeah, Solid's API works on the document level, not the triple level. It seems that generally it's best to store individual triples (or closely related triples that can all define a record) as separate documents in pods.

content.body: Hi all, based on the meeting earlier today, if anyone is interested in experimenting with a group pod, membership, etc, we can set up a solid-practioners group pod on TrinPod - just let me know your webid or you can get a free one at trinapp.com
image.png

A group pod has its own webid (which can be granted access to other pods as well as have groups under it) and all in the group can then collaborate - membership is via the vcard:hasMember predicate.  So for the bike effort as well as the smart city effort, groups or organization/sub-organiztion pods can be a good way to organize information and grant access to many members rather than having to copy things around
ü•≥ https://id.danielbakas.com/
Thanks gibsonf1 (Fred Gibson)
content.formatted_body: Thanks gibsonf1 (Fred Gibson)

content.body: Hi again everyone!! I wanted to share an interesting conversation elf-pavlik (elf Pavlik) and I were having over at the #solid/specification room about basic information retrieval of Identity Providers and related agents and classes
content.formatted_body: Hi again everyone!! I wanted to share an interesting conversation elf-pavlik (elf Pavlik) and I were having over at the #solid/specification room about basic information retrieval of Identity Providers and related agents and classes

content.body: Is this the right time and place to share what we discussed? ü§ì
Unless it relates to a library or application being used by one of the projects in this group, the app-development channel might be a better one.

As I understood our conversation, it wasn't about specific app or library. More about offering solid as service, which can include as package or separately:
* hosted solid storages (resource server + authorization server)
* hosted oidc provider
* hosted webids
* hosted (SAI) authorization agent
* hosted various notification related services
content.formatted_body:
As I understood our conversation, it wasn't about specific app or library. More about offering solid as service, which can include as package or separately:

  • hosted solid storages (resource server + authorization server)
  • hosted oidc provider
  • hosted webids
  • hosted (SAI) authorization agent
  • hosted various notification related services

content.body: And of course hosted solid application(s)
Those are all wonderful things, I  don't see how they relate to the needs of current projects.  This group is for supporting work currently being done, not what might might be done in the future.
I think many of the projects depend on users having many of those services available. Especially if projects wants to focus on providing a solid application.

I recall this comment I made a while ago about on-boarding which starts from an application: https://github.com/solid/solid-oidc/issues/77#issuecomment-654478888

> I see IdP as much higher priority role (especially if it hosts WebID) than any single client application. For that reason I would really hesitate to encourage applications to suggest specific IdP to the user.
content.formatted_body:
I recall this comment I made a while ago about on-boarding which starts from an application: https://github.com/solid/solid-oidc/issues/77#issuecomment-654478888

I see IdP as much higher priority role (especially if it hosts WebID) than any single client application. For that reason I would really hesitate to encourage applications to suggest specific IdP to the user.

And thus, not only provide the user with more options, choice and freedom (the whole purpose of Solid) but also expanding the possible reach of a Solid-OIDC provider, while also reducing the load for developers

content.body: The data in particular is PII related to receiving government services. And indeed our goal here is to make it shareable with other apps. Perhaps "app specific" isn't the right term. Perhaps "domain specific" is better. However, since this data is PII, we need to communicate the user "data stored here should be kept confidential" vs the web ID where it's always public and shouldn't contain confidential information.
When the user decides to switch to another app, will the data specific to your app become useless for them and they should just delete it as they revoke any authorizations they gave to your app?

The data in particular is PII related to receiving government services. And indeed our goal here is to make it shareable with other apps. Perhaps "app specific" isn't the right term. Perhaps "domain specific" is better. However, since this data is PII, we need to communicate the user "data stored in this profile should be kept confidential" vs the web ID where it's always public and shouldn't contain confidential information. We're trying to figure out a way to make that clear to them. "Private" seems a little confusing too, because that sometimes means "only the owner can access it." That isn't the case here. The data should be shared, but only with specific people.
From SAI perspective that sounds like a Data Instance in a specific [Data Registration](https://solid.github.io/data-interoperability-panel/specification/#data-registration)

content.body: In principle all data should start as only accessible by the user (and their authorization agent). And needs to have an explicit policy set by the user to make it accessible by any other party, including the broad public.

I would find it interesting to read more details about your specific use case. Thinking about defining a shape tree that would be used for the data registration, maybe it could include a that authorization agent shouldn't create access policies that apply to the whole registration but always use `interop:SelectedInstances` scope. Again it's is hard to tell without knowing the exact use case.

content.body:
I'm working on an open source project called PASS. We have an intro section on our wiki (although the feature list is a bit dated):
https://github.com/codeforpdx/PASS/wiki/Introduction#overview-of-pass

The goal of the project is to make it easier for people to share data that can help them get government housing services with different government offices. Since our target demographic is non-technical, we're spending a lot of time thinking about how to communicate the security levels of different data in their pod to them.

We're building the data in question using this ontology:
https://hmis-interop.github.io/

I can also recall conversations about tag/label based access policies. For example data could be tagged `IRS`, `DMV` etc. and one could authorize app (or another agent) to access all `IRS` tagged resources, which would not apply to resources only tagged `DMV`. This could work if kind of data could be common across those two contexts and the user can't only rely on the kind of the data they set access policy to.
content.formatted_body: I can also recall conversations about tag/label based access policies. For example data could be tagged IRS, DMV etc. and one could authorize app (or another agent) to access all IRS tagged resources, which would not apply to resources only tagged DMV. This could work if kind of data could be common across those two contexts and the user can't only rely on the kind of the data they set access policy to.

content.body:
> For us at Semantyk, the user should only be concerned with whether their data is public or private

Ah this may be the difference in our use case then. For the PASS project we have at least 3 cases:

- The data is public: any agent can access it (e.g. webIDs)
- The data is private: only the user can access it (e.g. app theme settings)
- The data is shared within a limited network: The user has granted some set of permissions to a few people.

The goal of the app is to help people receive civic and welfare services, which requires sharing sensitive data with these servicers.

We want to make sure it's clear to the user what parts of their data is public, what part of their data is private, and what part of their data is shared with the network.

An example of where this could be confusing is with the user's name, which can exist in multiple spaces. The webId may contain a nickname for yourself. It need not be your real name, it can be a pseudonym.

However, for the data we share with civic services, we need to get the person's legal name (otherwise the civic group may not be able to provide services). The rub is that many users will not want to make their legal name public.

content.body:
> <@danielbakas:matrix.org> Although if we know for sure that a Project is an Organization, we place it under Organizations instead, as a sub organization of the parent, and then define their Products and Services in Projects

I find it much cleaner to have a Project being a form of Organization that has members and produces/offers products and services.  That way the ProductOrService description does not have to get involved with things like organizational units, memberships, organization type, etc. those would all be handled in the Organization/Profile resource.

Now that i think about it, one issue with webhook notifications is that CSS implementation drops the subscription after 20 or something days (for memory reasons i think). So one needs to re-subscribe regularly when that happens.
Also, i don't remember exactly, but i think it doesn't give that much detail what has changed.
And last but not least, since everybody can POST to the webhook endpoint, you can't trust that the notification actually came from the server, and may need to verify that it's true.

Hopefully the benefits still outweight the issues, i guess you have to try and decide for yourselves. ü§î

content.body: My two cents: I was really insecure about scribing at first, and overtime it became my favorite thing to do at meetings :) I feel it is a really good way to contribute when I perhaps feel I don't have much insight on certain topics, and it is a really good way to pick up on knowledge because I have to be actively listening. A good way to go about it is to have a main scribe but one or two people supporting, filling in missed stuff, and so on. Taking turns is great because it does end up being the case that the same people end up scribing, see scribes charts here for example for some data on who are the usual scribes in CG meetings :) https://virginiabalseiro.github.io/solid-ecosystem-monitor/

content.body:
**Seeking Collaboration and Guidance for Our Conceptual SOLID-based Project**

Dear SOLID Community,

We are excited to introduce our project, aligned with SOLID's principles, aiming to revolutionise how technical professionals manage their career data. Not only how to manage their personal information but also how this information is shared with others. At the core, we focus on data sovereignty, standardisation, interoperability, and empowering users in data ownership.

Currently in the conceptual phase, we're building a tool for personal data management that integrates data across various technical platforms. Our primary objectives are:

- **Facilitating Personal Data Management**: Creating a unified interface for user data control.
- **Enhancing Data Interoperability**: Ensuring seamless data flow across platforms, adhering to SOLID principles.
- **Promoting User Ownership**: Giving users full control over their digital identities.

In our research, we've engaged with pivotal SOLID repositories like [Soukai Solid](https://github.com/NoelDeMartin/soukai-solid), [Solid Data Modules](https://github.com/solid-contrib/data-modules?tab=readme-ov-file), and [solid-contrib/solid-takeout-import](https://github.com/solid-contrib/solid-takeout-import).

We seek guidance on:

1. **Tool and Technology Adaptation**: Advice on tools and technologies for transitioning to design and implementation.
2. **Collaboration with Projects**: Opportunities to contribute to projects aligned with our vision.
3. **Ontology and Standards**: Insights on using standards like vCard and FOAF for our data model.

As newcomers, we're keen to integrate into the community. We've joined the SOLID forum and Gitter channel and would appreciate guidance on other key forums and their formats.

We look forward to contributing to and collaborating within the SOLID community. Your insights will be invaluable in shaping our project.

Thank you for the warm welcome.

Best regards!
content.formatted_body:
Seeking Collaboration and Guidance for Our Conceptual SOLID-based Project

Dear SOLID Community,

We are excited to introduce our project, aligned with SOLID's principles, aiming to revolutionise how technical professionals manage their career data. Not only how to manage their personal information but also how this information is shared with others. At the core, we focus on data sovereignty, standardisation, interoperability, and empowering users in data ownership.

Currently in the conceptual phase, we're building a tool for personal data management that integrates data across various technical platforms. Our primary objectives are:

  • Facilitating Personal Data Management: Creating a unified interface for user data control.
  • Enhancing Data Interoperability: Ensuring seamless data flow across platforms, adhering to SOLID principles.
  • Promoting User Ownership: Giving users full control over their digital identities.

In our research, we've engaged with pivotal SOLID repositories like Soukai Solid, Solid Data Modules, and solid-contrib/solid-takeout-import.

We seek guidance on:

  1. Tool and Technology Adaptation: Advice on tools and technologies for transitioning to design and implementation.
  2. Collaboration with Projects: Opportunities to contribute to projects aligned with our vision.
  3. Ontology and Standards: Insights on using standards like vCard and FOAF for our data model.

As newcomers, we're keen to integrate into the community. We've joined the SOLID forum and Gitter channel and would appreciate guidance on other key forums and their formats.

We look forward to contributing to and collaborating within the SOLID community. Your insights will be invaluable in shaping our project.

Thank you for the warm welcome.

Best regards!

content.body:
The thing is that for building that proof of concept, we have some doubts related with solid servers and custom ontologies, among other technical stuff.

We have seen that there are several approaches to the solid server (NSS, CSS, ESS, use.id, Trinpod, etc.). Which one better fits our needs for building a PoC? It would be useful at the beginning just implementing a simple flow:

Write to a pod
Read from a pod
Authenticate a user
Which programming language is more supported to develop the whole functional app within the PoC?

When it comes to trying to standardise the way individuals represent their personal career information, we have seen that there exist some ontologies like vcard, foaf or doac. What is the process of enriching those ontologies with our own proposal? At which point in development do you think it may have more importance? How is it the process of creating your own ontology?

Thanks in advance!
I also think Perl has some good libs for RDF, but again, not sure about Solid tools. If you're interested in Perl, you could try contacting Kjetil Kjernsmo

My two cents: I was really insecure about scribing at first, and overtime it became my favorite thing to do at meetings :) I feel it is a really good way to contribute when I perhaps feel I don't have much insight on certain topics, and it is a really good way to pick up on knowledge because I have to be actively listening. A good way to go about it is to have a main scribe but one or two people supporting, filling in missed stuff, and so on. Taking turns is great because it does end up being the case that the same people end up scribing, see scribes charts here for some data on who are the usual scribes in CG meetings :) generally it is the same 2-3 people. https://virginiabalseiro.github.io/solid-ecosystem-monitor/

content.body: For our PoC project, we've had some good success using community solid server. It's installed through node, so easy to send out to dev workstations. It's a no-frills server that seeks only to implement the solid standard, so if you write your code against that, it should (theoretically) work against most of the other servers you listed. It can also be extended with modules, so you can experiment with a nonstandard feature if you feel so inclined.
Javascript definitely has the best support for solid apps. I think there are also a few java libraries floating around as well

Yes! What Tim said. To add to that, regarding choice of ontology you can refer to https://github.com/pdsinterop/conventions. To enrich vcard/foaf/doac with your own proposal, just write your app and then we'll simply document your data format in the conventions (you can PR this yourself) and add your format to the relevant Solid Data Module
To get started, I recommend Inrupt's getting started tutorial https://docs.inrupt.com/developer-tools/javascript/client-libraries/tutorial/getting-started/
I would recommend using JavaScript or Typescript; I've created https://rdfjs.dev/ as an educational tool to help devs understand how you can combine RDF and JS, it might be helpful for you ^_^

Hello all. An announcement about [Solvent](https://github.com/manomayam/solvent).

Solvent lets us use Solid apps in native context over filesystem. We can create pod views over  folders, configure root uri for them to be simulated, and run packaged apps over them.

It will thus enable us to code apps against solid storage api with web ui stack, and ship them as native apps against user's file system. The final binaries are very small, (7-15 MB).

It is powered by [Manas](https://github.com/manomayam/manas) for storage abstraction, and Tauri for ui. Can use all sorts of tauri plugins and ecosystem.

Currently SolidOs is packaged, and [binaries](https://github.com/manomayam/solvent/releases/tag/solvent-v0.0.0) are shipped. Request you all to try and provide feedback.

I believe, once the project become stable, this could make Solid an attractive storage api to code web & native apps with single code base. With proper support it can be extended to offer sync solutions, native-first apps, etc in future.

üôè

Hello all. An announcement about Solvent.

Solvent lets us use Solid apps in native context over filesystem. We can create pod views over folders, configure root uri for them to be simulated, and run packaged apps over them.

It will thus enable us to code apps against solid storage api with web ui stack, and ship them as native apps against user's file system. The final binaries are very small, (7-15 MB).

It is powered by Manas for storage abstraction, and Tauri for ui. Can use all sorts of tauri plugins and ecosystem.

Currently SolidOs is packaged, and binaries are shipped. Request you all to try and provide feedback.

I believe, once the project become stable, this could make Solid an attractive storage api to code web & native apps with single code base. With proper support it can be extended to offer sync solutions, native-first apps, etc in future.

I am sorry, I could not participate in the meeting. I am on the trip, just with a phone, and internet is not always good here.

For short self introduction I can say that I am running small advertisement business in Russia, and that I like to write code in lisps (Racket, Clojure), used them for automation of business operations.
Before this I lived on the border Norway-Russia where took part or initiated several crossborder projects, this or that way related to make information in the area more accessible to its inhabitants, both Russians and Norwegians.
In 2018 I knew out about ontologies and since then tried to apply them in my projects, from this efforts I gradually have come to my domain-specific language Tabtree, intended to describe ontologies and data in modular and hierarchical way.

I knew out about Solid just recently, in December 2023, and had been inspired by fact, that the main format for describing data and PODs was chosen to be Turtle RDF. Just like what I use and love.  Also the idea of data, belonged to people, not companies/corporations is very beautiful.

As a vision, what I would like to reach - it is kind of "wikidata on pods", where people use data in p2p manner, and this helps to gather them into collaborative projects and cooperatives.
I can't join on Mondays at that time so no difference for me.

The issue is, if the member list is private, the server performing authorization (for a resource) has no way to fetch that list to check that the authenticated user (who requests the resource) is on it.
(Unless it can send a request authorized as the user, which I don't think is possible)

How does Trinpod solve this?

content.body:
We have a map of hosts, where a location of each host is in a different pod. To display them on the map, we iterate on the list of members and make a request to their pod asking about the location.

So we need a geospatial index that will return all points (hosts' locations) in a given range (rectangle area). 

One day, when there are more communities, we may want to display the members of other communities on the same map, so for that we would need a federated (?) index.

michal/mrkvon can probably provide more details.
content.formatted_body: We have a map of hosts, where a location of each host is in a different pod. To display them on the map, we iterate on the list of members and make a request to their pod asking about the location. So we need a geospatial index that will return all points (hosts' locations) in a given range (rectangle area). One day, when there are more communities, we may want to display the members of other communities on the same map, so for that we would need a federated (?) index. michal/mrkvon can probably provide more details.

content.body:
What if to have a separate community pod which will hold geospatial index for its members and provide this data to the app? 
Thus it would be possible to avoid for app to store spatial indexes in its own store.
But the app, of course, will still query coordinates and build geosp index, dumping data into the corresponded community pods.

The same community pod could be used for various cases, not only for hosting.

For example, local communities on my example: the same people have need to coordinate activities in running. But also with group ordering of sauna or in gathering to play mafia.

These activities could be supported  by different solid apps, but the community pod with various aggregated data, that doesn't belong to particular user - would be only one.

Though, I feel, the notion of community pod can be overcomplication...

A community for us is a list (group) of members who grant access to [some of] their data to other members of the group plus some metadata (like the index).

For the safety of the community, and the people who are part of it, there needs to be some governance of the community and it's assets in place, it's better to name it explicitly because otherwise too bad things can happen. So personally I don't feel like it's an overcomplication, to have a community pod.
for me now works too, thanks ewingson

content.body: I second the idea of using a group pod with its own webid and members to store the locations of members in that one location - then the app can get all locations with a single request.
Also members can have information etc in the group pod that only they can see, chat, etc.

This also supports the idea that members may not always want others to know where they are, so the source of truth location in each members pod can be updated in group pod when member wants it to or not - maybe a sync on and sync off kind of thing
You can also them give all members of that group access to things by simply using that group webid with just one acl

I still don't grok how group webId is useful compared to (just) group uri, especially in context when member gives resource access to other members of the group.

It was also mentioned in the past that group webId can allow groups to be non-public, and still be used for access control, and I still don't understand how.

The issue is hinted upon in [CSS#1441](https://github.com/CommunitySolidServer/CommunitySolidServer/issues/1442#issuecomment-1229842295)

Can you elaborate?

content.body: if you have a personal pod and make a uri there for a group, it means really the group is all managed out of that personal pod.  If you have a group pod, on the other hand, one or members can control the pod, all the discussions and information and chat among the group can go in that pod, and that group can collaborate with others via their webid

content.body:
My understanding is that SleepyBike is a `doap:Project`, with contributors, maintainers, etc. In a fully Solidified world, it would have a WebID and a pod which would contain at least

* a `vcard:Group` of people with write/merge access to the SleepyBike pod/repo.
* a `vcard:Group` of people registered on the SleepyBike website as hosts.
* a `vcard:Group` of people registered on the SleepyBike website as guests.

The `vcard:Group`s contain WebIDs of their members which are used to provide or deny them access to parts of the pod.
content.formatted_body:
My understanding is that SleepyBike is a doap:Project, with contributors, maintainers, etc. In a fully Solidified world, it would have a WebID and a pod which would contain at least

  • a vcard:Group of people with write/merge access to the SleepyBike pod/repo.

  • a vcard:Group of people registered on the SleepyBike website as hosts.

  • a vcard:Group of people registered on the SleepyBike website as guests.


The vcard:Groups contain WebIDs of their members which are used to provide or deny them access to parts of the pod.

content.body: Also, because of our triple level acls, we do not make membership public unless the group wants membership to be public
For example, the group pod I made for the practioners does not make members public at the moment: https://solid-practioners.trinpod.us/i

Thank you for elaborating!

If I want to share a document on my pod with members of such a group via acl:agentGroup, would it work?
You wouldn't need to - anything on the group pod can be readable by the group (and writable too) if you just add an acl at the root with default using the group webid
Oh wait, sorry, yes, you can share with the group that way using the webid from your pod

content.body:
Hi there :)

I am considering Solid (or the Solid-spec., not fully firm with the terms yet) for a project of mine. And i was wondering about its status: Is it something one would suggest for production use?

And in case i am in the wrong place here: I'll gladly take an pointers on where to ask the question. ("Practitioners" is what got me ;-)
Wilfred, I don't know what you handle is here, however on your Smart City effort with IOT that is something we are exactly working on with our Digital Twin approach

> <@0ftl:matrix.org> Hi there :)
> 
> I am considering Solid (or the Solid-spec., not fully firm with the terms yet) for a project of mine. And i was wondering about its status: Is it something one would suggest for production use?
> 
> And in case i am in the wrong place here: I'll gladly take an pointers on where to ask the question. ("Practitioners" is what got me ;-)

I think it depends on the use-case, and the biggest issue for "production use" is what your expectations are about user's PODs.

But mostly, yes, I'd say it can be used in production and some people (many of them in this group) are already doing it.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @0ftl:matrix.org
Hi there :)

content.body:
> <@mrkvon:matrix.org> The issue is, if the member list (foaf:Group) is private, the server performing authorization (for a resource) has no way to fetch that list to check that the authenticated user (who requests the resource) is on it.
> (Unless it can send a request authorized as the user, or make some limited query)
> 
> How does Trinpod solve this?

Solid does not divide the world into "public" and "private" - there is a space in between for shared resources.  If the WebID profile of the organization has rdfs:seeAlso links to group lists A, B, and C, and permissions them so that only members of A can read A and only members of B can read B, they are at least private from members not in the group.  It's true that if you want each member to have access without other members of that group knowing they are a member, there is no easy solution I am aware of.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to@mrkvon:matrix.org

The issue is, if the member list (foaf:Group) is private, the server performing authorization (for a resource) has no way to fetch that list to check that the authenticated user (who requests the resource) is on it.
(Unless it can send a request authorized as the user, or make some limited query)

How does Trinpod solve this?

Solid does not divide the world into "public" and "private" - there is a space in between for shared resources. If the WebID profile of the organization has rdfs:seeAlso links to group lists A, B, and C, and permissions them so that only members of A can read A and only members of B can read B, they are at least private from members not in the group. It's true that if you want each member to have access without other members of that group knowing they are a member, there is no easy solution I am aware of.

content.body:
> <@jeff-zucker:matrix.org> There are several threads of discussion in the Practitioners that could lead to several different specs.  I think the indexing that @lecoqlibre-5c1b5e25d73408ce4fb27c24:gitter.im is working on is super important and should be easy to integrate into the type-indexes spec.  A second thread is related to search interface - what sort of query string should it expect.  That would be a harder sell since it requires the server to do things but it needs discussing.

I'm wondering if we should not instead propose a spec next to the type-indexes spec. Indeed, we are working on a mechanism to index any property of the resources (not only the type).

The Type Index (TI) is designed AFAIK to index "big things" like Tim Berners-Lee said once if I remember correctly. In my understanding TI is more oriented on data discovery of first level kind of things and can also serve to discover the "entry points" of applications. TI is intended to be shared by applications evolving in business domains which could be different (a contact app, a photo app, a chat app, etc) so TI is "horizontal" or cross-domain.

The indexes I demoed are used by applications evolving in the same business domain (following the same client-client standard). They should be used "vertically". Theses indexes are also not limited to index only "big things" but are more granular and could be used for whatever the applications need to index.

In other words I would say the two kinds of index previously mentioned are in fact complementary. Applications can use both (and probably at least TI in many cases). Even if we can use the demoed indexes vocabulary to replace some part of the current TI, I would say that we still need a TI spec to keep a dedicated simple cross-domain data discovery mechanism. Then we can perhaps write a separated spec to define a "standard" way to index things for vertical use.

content.body: Agreed, ` solid:forClass schema:Photo; solid:instance </link/to/a/Photo/index>.` sounds wrong, `solid:forClass schema:PhotoLibrary; solid:instance </link/to/a/Photos/index#this>.` sounds better.  Then the photo library has domain-specfic indexes  by aperture, exposure, date, keywords, say.
content.formatted_body: Agreed, solid:forClass schema:Photo; solid:instance </link/to/a/Photo/index>. sounds wrong, solid:forClass schema:PhotoLibrary; solid:instance </link/to/a/Photos/index#this>. sounds better. Then the photo library has domain-specfic indexes by aperture, exposure, date, keywords, say.

content.body:
> <@timbl-54d26c98db8155e6700f7312:gitter.im> Agreed, ` solid:forClass schema:Photo; solid:instance </link/to/a/Photo/index>.` sounds wrong, `solid:forClass schema:PhotoLibrary; solid:instance </link/to/a/Photos/index#this>.` sounds better.  Then the photo library has domain-specfic indexes  by aperture, exposure, date, keywords, say.

I guess the content of `</link/to/a/Photos/index>` depends on what the `schema:PhotoLibrary` is supposed to be. In your example, the `schema:PhotoLibrary` still point to an index, right?

If the PhotoLibrary is more than an index, the TI could be:
```
<#ab09fd> a solid:TypeRegistration;
     solid:forClass schema:PhotoLibrary;
     solid:instance </link/to/a/PhotoLibrary#this>.
```

The content of the `</link/to/a/PhotoLibrary>` could look like:
```
<> a schema:PhotoLibraryDocument.

<#this> a schema:PhotoLibrary;
    ex:index </link/to/an/aperture/index>, 
             </link/to/an/exposure/index>, 
             </link/to/a/keywords/index>.
```

Then an example of the `</link/to/a/keywords/index>` could be:
```
<> a ex:Index, schema:KeywordsIndex;
    ex:forProperty schema:hasKeyword.

<#1> a ex:PropertyIndexRegistration;
    ex:forValue "sunset";
    ex:instance </link/to/a/sunset/photo.jpg>.
    
<#2> a ex:PropertyIndexRegistration;
    ex:forValue "flower";
    ex:instance </link/to/a/flower/photo.jpg>.
```

I was thinking about the hackathon idea that was mentioned a few times recently, I myself don't have experience with hackathons but michal/mrkvon was concerned with their competitive nature.

timbot1789 said they would be happy to participate in a hackathon with PASS project. 

I remember a friend of mine from Chicago who co-founded https://www.pieforproviders.com/ project participated in a create-a-thon organised by https://democracylab.org/ who are based in Seattle... what makes me suspect there is possibly better hackathon culture in the US (West coast?) then in Europe, what Michal experienced.

What if we collaboratively made first hackathon dedicated to PASS and then second one to sleepy.bike, and possibly others?

Hello practitioners üëã I would like to ask you all about your current and planned workflow for localization. In the UI for my reference implementation of SAI Authorization Agent I went with https://projectfluent.org/ 
Since I use Vue it was very easy thanks to https://fluent-vue.demivan.me/
Now I would like to set up a project on an online platform to accept contributions for other languages, Mozilla has open source project for that https://github.com/mozilla/pontoon
Sadly I couldn't find a public deployment welcoming open source projects, Pontoon has easy deployment to Heroku but it doesn't make sense for me to do it for just one or eventually a handful of projects I plan to work on.
I would like to know how do you manage localization of your projects and if you are still in the planning phase would you be interested in finding a common place to deploy Mozilla's Pontoon, not sure if Solid Project would be open to host it.
As I mentioned during one of the first calls, I see localization crucial to easily adopt open source projects, which are successful in one part of the world, to other parts of the world.

I looked at it but didn't see support for Fluent, now I double checked and indeed they do have a beta support for it https://docs.weblate.org/en/latest/formats/fluent.html
So far I was able to import translations from my project, will still need to fiddle with it but so for it looks promising. Thanks a lot michal/mrkvon

In Trustroots in particular, many community members can - and do - contribute translations in their native language this way. Weblate has relatively nice and intuitive interface.

content.body: image.png
Look for this ‚¨ÜÔ∏è at the bottom of the pricing page.
e.g. https://hosted.weblate.org/projects/trustroots/

I looked at it but didn't see support for Fluent, now I double checked and indeed they do have a beta support for it https://docs.weblate.org/en/latest/formats/fluent.html
So far I was able to import translations from my project, will still need to fiddle with it but so for it looks promising. Thanks a lot michal/mrkvon

content.body: (speaking for myself only, I keep forgetting that I should not make assumptions about what others will do)

Speaking for myself again - I don't have any issues with competition, algorithmic programming challenges is actually what got me into computer science - I was really obsessed at solving them.

So personally I probably wouldn't mind some competition, a satisfaction from a hard problem being solved is a great reward for me.

Thanks for your understanding.

content.body:
Yes, I think hackathons are a great way to find solutions to some of the hardest problems of Solid, as they create an opportunity to match owners of both. 

The more diverse the pool of solutions, the better! If something is a thought problem, it is always in the context of popular approaches to it, so a new one needs to be looked for.

content.formatted_body:
In reply to @elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im
Hello practitioners üëã I would like to ask you all about your current and planned workflow for localization. In the UI for my reference implementation of SAI Authorization Agent I went with https://projectfluent.org/
Since I use Vue it was very easy thanks to https://fluent-vue.demivan.me/
Now I would like to set up a project on an online platform to accept contributions for other languages, Mozilla has open source project for that https://github.com/mozilla/pontoon
Sadly I couldn't find a public deployment welcoming open source projects, Pontoon has easy deployment to Heroku but it doesn't make sense for me to do it for just one or eventually a handful of projects I plan to work on.
I would like to know how do you manage localization of your projects and if you are still in the planning phase would you be interested in finding a common place to deploy Mozilla's Pontoon, not sure if Solid Project would be open to host it.
As I mentioned during one of the first calls, I see localization crucial to easily adopt open source projects, which are successful in one part of the world, to other parts of the world.
Penny uses Fluent too, and Weblate supports it too and does have a public deployment welcoming open source projects, e.g. https://hosted.weblate.org/projects/penny/ui/

> As I mentioned during one of the first calls, I see localization crucial to easily adopt open source projects, which are successful in one part of the world, to other parts of the world.

I agree that localization is very important :). I've only translated my latest app, but I plan to translate others as well. However, I don't have much experience with translations in my own projects and because of what I've seen elsewhere I'm not sure what's the best way to add languages that I don't speak :/.

I don't mean that I'm not sure which tech to use, but how to make sure that the contributions have enough quality and that they won't get abandoned if the application evolves. For now I just linked to this disclaimer for anyone who wants to contribute, but so far I haven't gotten any: https://github.com/NoelDeMartin/umai/blob/main/docs/contribute-translations.md

content.body: My guess is that many people capable of contributing great translations will be intimidated with git and editing yaml. That's where tools like weblate come in the picture. On the other hand it's great that you advertise it in the app... :)

Yeah, well I do mention that if anyone doesn't know how to use github they can send me the translations and I'll update the app myself. Though I understand reading that document may discourage some people from contributing rather than encouraging them üòÖ I'm not convinced that something like this will be the final form of how I manage contributions, but I prefer to start like this and automate later on. I prefer not to spend time in hypothetical problems, and if nobody is contributing now I don't think a lot more would contribute if I have a proper platform for translations.
Right, I have no idea if translation UI would help either...

content.body:
Not sure what you're asking. Intention is for sleepy.bike (which is single-page web app written with React) to work with different Pod providers - currently works ok with NSS and CSS. The webhookChannel-dependent implementation of email notification service works well with CSS, but not with NSS. The solid-notification-independent version works fine at least with NSS and CSS.

Both of the mentioned email notification services are dedicated servers written with koa and typescript. They use Solid-OIDC for authentication. I think i wrote some details in both repositories' README, if you want to read more. Or you can ask. üôÇ

I hope this makes some sense, and i can also elaborate if you have specific questions.

Not sure what you're asking. Intention is for sleepy.bike (which is single-page web app written with React) to work with different Pod providers - currently works ok with NSS and CSS. The webhookChannel-dependent implementation of email notification service works well with CSS, but not with NSS. The solid-notification-independent version works fine at least with NSS and CSS.

Both of the mentioned email notification services are dedicated servers written with koa and typescript. They use Solid-OIDC for authentication. I think i wrote some details in both repositories' README, if you want to read more. Or you can ask. üôÇ

I hope this makes some sense, and i can also elaborate if you have specific questions.

content.body: I am just trying to understand your use case. Main intention was to see which POD providers you are able to support esp. vis-a-vis notifications (or where majority of  your users are coming from)  because that lets me gauge how useful their current implementation state is in the real world. NSS has no notifications though Alain is exploring that right now. It would have been interesting if someone "accidentally" brought ESS pods just to see how well they work.

content.body:
Thanks, that's a lot of resources! 

I don't speak German, but I have a solid computer science background (MSc from Jagiellonian University and ENS de Lyon) and I worked as a software engineer i.a. at IBM Cloud Object Storage (formerly Cleversafe). I have most experience in Java/JVM ecosystem and distributed systems, that I kind of specialised in. Never did web development or JavaScript, but had an exposure to a variety of different programming languages and decentralised software architectures. I liked algos and data structures most, and things related to programming languages themselves. I am dyslexic so I am kind of naturally attracted to any topics related to code readability, different programming paradigms, syntax expressiveness etc.

So I guess technically it's probably not too specialised, but I would most like to find some very high-level vision resources that will spark my heart and something very narrow that I can start with to focus on. Might be some small code contributions, but it is hard for me to motivate myself to work in JS, for too many reasons.

I would be interested to participate in the discussion. When Polymer came out I made few prototypes, later used its successor LitElement once or twice. It has been a while but I recall that web components are relatively simple, just props down, events up and slots. Back in the days I was using them with Redux, I guess there would still be a need for some higher level connected components / containers which would use one of the solid clients.
mine are all based on rdflib and communica - a simple html can run SPARQL and other queries, display and update forms, pull RDF, etc.
content.formatted_body: mine are all based on rdflib and communica - a simple html can run SPARQL and other queries, display and update forms, pull RDF, etc.

> <@elf-pavlik-53f689c8163965c9bc1ffb15:gitter.im> i'm curiuous how the dependencies are managed, i recall back in Polymer days they were trying to use yarn as default package manager to use it's flat dependency install, otherwise bundles would end up with multiple different versions of the same dependency

But you are right that something like rdflib would not be shared by default between two unrelated libs ,since both would bundle it independently. content.body: This may be relevant for the web components efforts https://custom-elements-everywhere.com/

A question I've run into is interoperability in how reactive rendering works across web components. My preferred approach at the moment is to use a central state with web components subscribing to changes (currently implemented with rdflib.js by listening for added or new triples using a particular subject). Not immediately compatible with other components that refresh a vdom tree through properties/attributes.
CC vinnl
content.formatted_body: CC vinnl

content.body: Same, mine all share the store and authenticated fetcher and since I use neither frameworks nor shadow-dom, they should play well with others, excited to see how all our work can merge

content.body:
> <@mariha:matrix.org> I am a bit confused with my recent interactions, and I might have confused people with indirect communication when joining the room. Usually I communicate very directly, and with the message above I didn't want to say that I have anything against Inrupt hackathons (just in case it was understood like this).
> sleepy.bike won one of them, but as I remember I didn't participate in the hackathon activities except making the explainer / demo, so it's hard to say that I have any experiences, good or bad... I was happy for our three-people team at the time that we won üéâ.
> I am also confusing speaking for myself as an individual (first part of this and the above message) and speaking as a project representative (second part of this and the above message). We haven't figured it out internally in the project what is our structure or outside communication style, what came out recently in the context of the presentation, and we are doing it right now (mostly internally). 
> Thanks for your understanding.

An update from the sleepy.bike project: we still didn't find a way forward from the stalemate we had reached with the events accompanying our project's presentation at last Solid World. 

I don't know how to speak about what happened while respecting Michal's standards of privacy, but I wanted to voice out somehow the very difficult situation we have.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @mariha:matrix.org

I am a bit confused with my recent interactions, and I might have confused people with indirect communication when joining the room. Usually I communicate very directly, and with the message above I didn't want to say that I have anything against Inrupt hackathons (just in case it was understood like this).

sleepy.bike won one of them, but as I remember I didn't participate in the hackathon activities except making the explainer / demo, so it's hard to say that I have any experiences, good or bad... I was happy for our three-people team at the time that we won üéâ.

I am also confusing speaking for myself as an individual (first part of this and the above message) and speaking as a project representative (second part of this and the above message). We haven't figured it out internally in the project what is our structure or outside communication style, what came out recently in the context of the presentation, and we are doing it right now (mostly internally).

Thanks for your understanding.

An update from the sleepy.bike project: we still didn't find a way forward from the stalemate we had reached with the events accompanying our project's presentation at last Solid World.

I don't know how to speak about what happened while respecting Michal's standards of privacy, but I wanted to voice out somehow the very difficult situation we have.

Hi Solid Community,

We're a passionate startup from Australia, and we've recently been inspired by the Solid project. Its principles resonate deeply with our vision of a more decentralised, user-controlled internet, and we're excited to integrate Solid into our offerings by providing pods for our clients.

As non-technical founders, we've been diving into the project, but we know there's a lot more to learn and many ways to collaborate. We're looking to connect with anyone who has experience with Solid, whether you're a freelancer, developer, or simply someone who can offer guidance.

We‚Äôd love to chat about how we can work together or if you could point us in the direction of someone in Australia or at Inrupt who might be interested in collaborating.

Looking forward to hearing from this amazing community!

Cheers,
Sai

Dear SOLID Community,

My name is Mohammad Bahrani, and I‚Äôm a research associate in the Web and Internet Science (WAIS) group at the University of Southampton. I‚Äôm currently working on a project focused on efficient, secure, and sovereign search over personal repositories across Solid pods. My main research contributions will be in the areas of information retrieval, large language models (LLMs), and federated learning within this context.

I‚Äôm excited to join the group and participate in the meetings and discussions, learn about your work, and share ideas. Looking forward to connecting with you all!

content.body: I hope next time there will be a better climate for honest greetings and welcoming words, sorry for forgetting about the conventions. Hi!
This change of license was illegal: https://github.com/solidcouch/solidcouch/blame/1ca1193366ff5b1f5feede182f24d64ea3a9f178/LICENSE

To clarify these concerns, I moved the [repository](https://github.com/solidcouch/solidcouch), which I authored almost entirely, into a new organization in August, and I [publicly announced it](https://mrkvon.org/blog/announcing-solidcouch). I respected the original MIT license [for all contributions that were not mine](https://github.com/solidcouch/solidcouch/pull/119). Despite suggesting mediation, there has been no resolution, and I will not engage further on this matter under current circumstances.

I regret that the conflict has come to this space. This will be my final statement on the matter here. If anybody has any concerns, please feel free to contact me directly. Thank you for your understanding.

I regret that the conflict has come to this space. This will be my final statement on the matter here. If anybody has any concerns, please feel free to contact me directly. Thank you for your understanding.

content.body:
Hey guys,

I have functional hyperandrogenism as a result of stress I was exposed to in recent years and I'll leave this space now with a hope to find some peace of mind / as means of self-protection.

Be aware that the Solid Code of Conduct committee does not answer requests due to transitioning under ODI so the presence of CoC gives a false sense of protection. I would consider removing it.

I hope you develop web 3.0 as an inclusive and safe space for everyone to participate. Good luck with that!

I enjoyed meeting with you in this group. I truly believed I would go back to Software Engineering when the time is right. My father died and I didn't expect to be used as cannon fodder, but I learnt how important it is to choose the right people for myself to partner with.

Best,
mariha
Travelling right now, will be more available in about a week.

I am deeply sorry to hear that this has happened.

I have [just made a post to the forums](https://forum.solidproject.org/t/code-of-conduct-committee/8150/2) announcing that ODI is now able to take on Ombuds activities - you can now send any CoC reports you have to solid-ombuds@theodi.org

I hope that we can all make the Solid Community a positive environment to build an inclusive, safe and ethical Web.

Interested in  the ActivityPods ideas aroud pods for groups -- the way it works in SolidOS, an Organization is an agent, a social entity, and has veruous related vcard groups of people (or other orgs).

Would be a great discussion to have. I initially thought that is what CODs would provide an avenue for until further explained by elf-pavlik (elf Pavlik) . I do believe there‚Äôs long-term interests in group support especially as there are ActivityPub platforms that operate on a ‚Äúgroup‚Äù model such as Reddit alternatives Kbin and Lemmy as well as forums which support ActivityPub such as Discourse and NodeBB

content.body: Eg https://solidproject.solidcommunity.net/Solid%20Project%20Contacts/index.ttl#this is an addressBook which ha the groups around the soolid project
Maybe pick up tech discussion of runnig AP on top of Solid ... I am curious what sort of a container AP has which Solid does not have

I think one of the things Solid is missing is a validation of inboxes. E.g. if I allow some subset of agents to append to a resource/container, they're able to add whatever [valid turtle] they want, and I won't even know who appended what. AFAIK AP or ActivityStreams suggest proper validation in the spec.

* I think one of the things Solid is missing is a validation of inboxes. E.g. if I allow some subset of agents to append to a resource/container, they're able to add whatever [valid turtle] they want, and I won't even know who appended what, except if they sign it.

content.body: Okay, thanks for the explanation.
And if the single subject has predicates pointing to other subjects, must those be in a separate document or could they be in the same document?
I agree but on the level of best practice rather than a MUST though any given app could insist I guess
We do not dissociate the subject and the document. So it is the main topic itself.

No they must be in a separate document. The reason why we cannot do that at the moment is that we use a triple store, not a quad store. When we will move to a quad store in version 3, all documents will be in their own named graph. So to get the content of a document, we will only need to fetch the content of the named graph.
Not sure what you mean there.  Is the URL of the subject the document or a document fragment?

I think one of the things Solid is missing is a validation of inboxes. E.g. if I allow some subset of agents to append to a resource/container, they're able to add whatever [valid turtle] they want, and I won't even know who appended what, except if they sign it.

content.body:
Hello All. (New to Solid)

I wanted to reach out and ask for advice to overcome a hurdle that is leaving me scratching my head. I am currently making attempts to deploy the NSS and seems like it does and does not work at the same time. I attempted to follow the documentation on Github and set up a reverse proxy using Nginx and link the server through the proxy_pass. The first issue I ran into was my SSL certificate did not like that the Solid server  domain name "localhost". I have since corrected that issue and now a face new problem. When I attempt to go to the domain that is attributed to the server my request times out, but if I curl the URL I get the index.html page. When I attempt to curl anywhere else besides the "/" for the domain I am hit with a 401 on the server side. I since figured out how to register a profile thinking that would let me at least gain access. However, even though I set up an account, I still am unable to access the server from a browser. Not sure what do here.  All advice is welcomed. 

Thank you.

content.body: Hi just wanted to follow up on my previous comment. I was able to resolve the issue an get the server up and running. What I initially thought was a cert mismatch or config issue was a really mismatch rule in the firewall.

Hi v3x4s I would first note that self-hosting is not a requirement to use Solid. If you want to sign up for a Pod on a server that is already deployed then you can use https://solidcommunity.net or any other already hosted instance listed in https://solidproject.org/for-developers.

If you do want to self-host, I would recommend going for the newer CommunitySolidServer (https://communitysolidserver.github.io/CommunitySolidServer/latest/) rather than the NodeSolidServer

Can I ask what are you looking to do with Solid - build apps, use apps, test things out? The answer might help guide the best approach for you.

content.body: it looks to me that the goal with MCP is to let the LLM (claude in this case) have access to some dataset. You can then use the prompts to manipulate this data. see examples here: https://glama.ai/blog/2024-11-25-model-context-protocol-quickstart
Does Claude use our data to train itself?
* Does Claude use our data to train itself?

m.new_content.body: Does Claude use our data to train itself?

content.body: My first intuition was totally different. I thought that the LLM would take the data (some RDF in our case) and process it into its Model in order to give more accurate answers based on contextualised data. But, as far as i understood so far, this i snot the case at all. Please anybody, tell me that i am wrong.
Claude is an LLM, created by Anthropic

> <@nikob:matrix.org> Claude is an LLM, created by Anthropic

Yes, I use it via Duck Duck Go which means it does not use its sessions with me to train itself ... Ideally we  can eventually have a pod-based llm that does learn from our sessions but only the local llm does the learning.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to@nikob:matrix.org
Claude is an LLM, created by Anthropic
Yes, I use it via Duck Duck Go which means it does not use its sessions with me to train itself ... Ideally we can eventually have a pod-based llm that does learn from our sessions but only the local llm does the learning.

content.body:
I am not sure if MCP is about the LLM learning anything. I know that their marketing is confusing. by example: they say MCP can provide "additional context to LLM-powered applications like Claude.ai. Think of it as a standardized way to feed external information into AI models".

But then the only examples I see are different. they are about using the prompt of Claude to query a dataset. Like you say you can query duckduckgo with Claude. Will Claude "learn" anything from your interactions with the dataset? I don't know. this is an open question for me at the moment
claude.png
With DuckDuckGo, the answer is no ^^
Note the message on the right saying that my session is not used to train the LLMs
I guess the men in Black wave their little wand after our conversations and Claude forgets.
Presumably DuckDuckGo or someone else can do the same for MCPs ... but ideally we could have our own models learn without training the company's model.

(I forgot that Jeff cannot use threads properly on his device. sorry about that).
Claude or any LLM can indeed improve their model when you use their centralized service/APIs and you gave consent (I guess). In the case of DuckDuckGo, the consent is no. That's one thing.
Now talking about MCP, seems to be another thing altogether.
It doesn't seem to me that Claude will learn anything from your interactions with datasets defined by MCP.
MCP is more like a connector to let you manipulate the dataset with Claude. It happens locally only, and the LLM in itself will not be modified by your local interactions with your MCP data sets. Correct me if I am wrong

I see!
So only if you run the LLM locally (which needs huge amount of resources, and needs also an open source LLM), then you never have control over privacy guarantees
And MCP will always send the data to the central servers of Anthropic?
That's how I understand it.  But hopefully there can be a combined remote and local LLM that uses computing power from the remote and data from local

content.body: maybe this is what MCP is all about. and in this case, your local data would not enrich the LLM... I guess
your own version of Claude, I bet not. as it is not open source
right, your own version of an open source llm
except a hybrid version that uses a central dataset plus your own or ability to connect to federated datasets

I think what MCP does eventually (but it is just a guess) is that it uses some abstract reasoning features that are already in the LLM, because Anthropic "taught" Claude how to use its MCP API. And then you can connect any kind of data that respects the MCP APIs/specs locally, and Claude will be able to manipulate and do some reasoning on it, without the need to send the local data to its central servers nor to integrate the data into the global model.

> <@jeff-zucker:matrix.org> The LLM has to see the data to process it.  Without guarantee it forgets my data, consent is meaningless.

No guarantee, but running a neural network today (and thus LLM) for training is more expensive than for predicting for each run. This due to the calculation of gradient descent for training (the data would likely be fed in multiple times too but that's not an absolute requirement for your data to be used). No guarantee, but at least there is an incentive.

content.body: I pay for storage costs on my server, but the server is also funded through OpenCollective. Object Storage for media is relatively inexpensive, so I can host a considerable amount of media files for a sustainable cost.

> <@jeswr-5f532665d73408ce4fee1daf:gitter.im> Ah brilliant üëè , Sean Tilley:  it would be good to know how much we can use. At a guess we'd have about 50GB work of video; (50 1hr videos that were approx 1gb at time of upload).
> I've also got a few questions:
> Does peertube automatically apply any compression?
> What is the data redundancy of of spectra.video like - if this is self hosted with your own storage rather than being an ipfs model; do you have reliable backups?
> Related to who pays for it, is it sustainable - what is the likelihood of the service being shut down / disappearing?

All good questions! There is no cap on uploads, due to Object Storage being quite affordable. 

1. All videos are transcoded into HLS, which optimizes for streaming on PeerTube's video player. 

2. I use an Object Storage layer separate from a self-hosted server. Linode has regular scheduled backups, last I checked they are daily. 

3. I have run the instance for almost two years now? Spectra utilizes an OpenCollective that has greatly helped in keeping the operation affordable as membership scales up.
