> <@timbl-54d26c98db8155e6700f7312:gitter.im> If the solid world stuff is 50GB is that in original form?  When Peer Tube compresses for streaming does it do that at multiple levels?

Hard for me to quantify, I would say that extant factors include multiple resolutions of videos. Broadly speaking, we encode whatever the original format is, plus a lower 360p resolution. So, let's say that you upload 50GB worth of video, you'd have that plus the smaller resolution version that gets generated. Let's estimate that to about 75GB, give or take.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @timbl-54d26c98db8155e6700f7312:gitter.im
If the solid world stuff is 50GB is that in original form? When Peer Tube compresses for streaming does it do that at multiple levels?
Hard for me to quantify, I would say that extant factors include multiple resolutions of videos. Broadly speaking, we encode whatever the original format is, plus a lower 360p resolution. So, let's say that you upload 50GB worth of video, you'd have that plus the smaller resolution version that gets generated. Let's estimate that to about 75GB, give or take.

content.body: I will state that Object Storage has largely made the cost of hosting the media files themselves somewhat negligible. I'm close to a terrabyte of media for my instance; Object Storage ensures that storage is utilized separately from my server application and hosting infrastructure.

The way that PeerTube works is simple: videos are not themselves federated across servers (except in cases of redundancy), but the metadata that effectively acts like a catalogue entry is what gets federated.
The PeerTube player utilizes some Peer to Peer functionality on the player end between viewers, but that's just chunks of video data to assist with loading.
I suppose the total storage depends on (a) what was the encoding of the original vs HLS output + how many resolutions are chosen to generate: https://docs.joinpeertube.org/admin/configuration

I wanted to spend a day playing around with new frontend frameworks since I haven't been hands on with front end for quite a while.

The result is https://solid-catalog.jeswr.org, which is another interface for viewing the Solid Catalog that Jeff Zucker is creating.

The stack used here was NextUI (UI Components) + Tailwind (Styling) + React + Typescript + Vercel (deployment) + LDO (by Jackson Morgan).

Jeff Zucker, niko at NextGraph.org and I are pleased to announce the [Solid Together](https://cxres.inrupt.net/public/SoSy25/solid-together/) session at the third [Solid Symposium](https://sosy2025.eu) in Leiden, Netherlands on 24-25 April 2025.

The [Solid Together](https://cxres.inrupt.net/public/SoSy25/solid-together/) session, organized by Solid Practitioners, aims to highlight the various projects around the world that use Solid to serve the greater good in society.

If you are participating in such a project, we invite you to speak at our session. If you know of someone working on such a project, please spread the word. You may submit your contributions by sending an e-mail to the organizers listed on the session [webpage](https://cxres.inrupt.net/public/SoSy25/solid-together/).

content.body:
[The ESPRESSO team](https://espressoproject.org/)  invites you to join our workshop on **Information Retrieval in Decentralized and/or Federated Systems** at [SoSy 2025](https://www.sosy2025.eu/).

This is an opportunity for practitioners from across the globe to meet face-to-face and learn how each
other's work is contributing to the challenges that matter in our communities.

Increasingly, the international community of Solid practitioners is looking at how we can query pods, and how we can query and search pods while taking into account Solid‚Äôs varying and dynamic access
permissions.

We expect that our workshop will be of particular interest to the wider Solid community, as
well as to the wider IR community, including those working with more traditional centralized
architectures.

This will be a hands-on session: if you have a project ready to demonstrate, demo it; if you have code
you're still working on, talk us through it; if you have a high-level design, walk us through it. Tell us about
the people your project is helping, has helped, or will help; and how.

The ESPRESSO team is developing a novel experimental framework to solve the critical problem in Solid's decentralized private web environment, which is this: **how do you search between Solid pods, when access to the resources in those pods depends on widely varying access rights?**

The advent of effective search engines was an inflection point in the public‚Äôs adoption of the World Wide Web. More recently, the disadvantages of the centralized paradigm in Web search are becoming more and more apparent, as previously popular search engines return poorer-quality or even erroneous results, and providers of alternative search engines aiming to provide better-quality results face difficulties in scaling
their offerings to return results of sufficient quality and relevance.

Privacy of search has been a priority
for alternative search engine providers for some years; and more recently, creators have been calling for more respect for their intellectual property rights in order to protect their work from being incorporated into AI (artificial intelligence) training data.

**ESPRESSO** is the first project to take on access rights as a first-class component of decentralized
search. We will open the session by demonstrating ESPRESSO's approach to a realistic scenario of
medical research over patient records in Solid pods.

During the session, IR practitioners will present their innovative solutions, and by the end, IR
practitioners working in Solid, FAIR, Linked Data, and adjacent fields will know how their work relates to
others.

**Organizers:** 

Helen Oliver, Birkbeck, University of London, [h.oliver@bbk.ac.uk](mailto:h.oliver@bbk.ac.uk); 

Mohammad Bahrani,
University of Southampton, [m.bahrani@soton.ac.uk](mailto:m.bahrani@soton.ac.uk)

If you‚Äôve been doing interesting things with Solid - whether it be in industry, academia, or elsewhere - please reach out to me using my email jesse.wright@theodi.org. For more details see https://forum.solidproject.org/t/solid-world-presenters/8590

Hi all,
I am looking for Solid Pod implementations where the UMA flow (as noted by the Solid-OIDC spec) is actually used. (NSS and CSS do not)
I am aware of Inrupt's ESS but was wondering if there is any other one... Does anyone here happen to know such implementation, or knows someone who (might) know... ?
Cheers!
I think @woutermont worked on it at some point, see for instance https://github.com/CommunitySolidServer/CommunitySolidServer/pull/1865#issuecomment-1999054318
Wouter also co-authored this one https://github.com/SolidLabResearch/UMA_Authorization_Server
Thanks!

content.body: Hey, all! We're launching a federated forum on We Distribute, powered by NodeBB and ActivityPub. It's capable of federating with Lemmy, PieFed, Mbin, and pretty much any Reddit-like platform in the Fediverse capable of this feature.
I wanted to highlight that we have a dedicated section for Solid, and if anyone is interested in joining and sharing cool stuff about Solid, they are more than welcome to join.
https://forum.wedistribute.org/category/10/solid-project
We're still experimenting, it's a new piece of our infra, but it's also set up to follow the Solid Practitioners PeerTube channel.
Lemmy and other Threadiverse platforms can discover it at: @solid@forum.wedistribute.org

Is there a library that provides authN for a non-website application, to READ a file it has access to? 

Hi, sorry I am new to practising Solid. I am trying to create a local Python program to connect to my Pod (https://solidcommunity.net/), and READ a file. On the Pod provider website I gave access to localhost:1234, and in my local program I am adding localhost:1234 as the origin in the header. I tried other headers like a Bearer with my webID token. 
I understand authN is difficult, so is there any guidance for how I can get a successful READ from a local program to a pod to work, without requiring the pod owner user in the request? Seen https://docs.inrupt.com/developer-tools/javascript/client-libraries/tutorial/authenticate-nodejs-web-server/# and https://github.com/jeff-zucker/solid-shell  and https://ldo.js.org/guides/solid\_react/#4-implementing-loginlogout-in-the-header

content.body: https://github.com/jeff-zucker/solid-file-client
Authentication outside of browsers is not standardised so this will not work with all servers
Oh ok I see, thank you! I see this issue for the specs is for server side apps auth: https://github.com/solid/specification/issues/504

Hi Areeba,
To follow what jesse said, Solid auth is based on OIDC which is ment for the web and ask for user interaction in order to sign in.  However, if your pod in hoster on a CSS instance, you can use the client credentials API, but this will make your script only work with CSS pod
Oh ok! Thank you!!
https://communitysolidserver.github.io/CommunitySolidServer/latest/usage/client-credentials/
Oh ok! Thank you!!

No, you have things mixed.  Solid-File-Client does not handle auth and works with any server given the right auth client. One needs to bring an auth-client to it.   Solid-File-Client can be used in a browser and outside a browser with Inrupt's or any other auth client.  It's ability to be used on a server is entirely dependent on what auth library you bring to it. Outside a browser, it can be used with my Solid-Node-Client which is a switcher for auth-clients that supports using either solid-auth-fetcher or Inrupt's solid-auth client.  It used to work with all servers, but changes in how ESS and CSS handle external clients means that it currently only works with NSS.

content.body: This might be a niche topic, but I've publish a repo for a program that will extract DICOM metadata as RDF.  I've created the program as I am building a system which will store DICOM Pathology and Radiology data in a Solid POD.  Just putting the DICOM binary assets in the POD was not enough for me so this program will extract additional metadata that can be queried via Solid protocol to supplement the base Solid metadata.  see https://github.com/ebremer/dcm2rdf
My slides from today; added links: https://hackmd.io/@mrkvon/Skh0gsVqkx#/

Awesome work! Indeed would be great to have on solidcommunity.net - since it is a CSS component it seems like it should work with Pivot ...

Also wanted to make a slightly off-topic remark to say that I'm increasingly impressed with code-editors using GenAI (https://blog.jeswr.org/2025/03/18/impressed-by-cursor).

I wrote this blog off the back of the LWS WG call on Monday where there was a discussion about getting the syntax right for some of the spec documents - and it turns out that copilots have become quite good at those kind of formatting tasks.

I quantify my success with co-pilots at 25% ... from introducing functions from other languages, to ad-infinitum "yes i see the mistake, let me generate again with the same mistake" they can help with some tasks but can be a burden at others. A couple of weeks ago I spent 7 days debugging some CYPHER query that the copilots generated - and it worked well on the CLI as parts (that's how it was built) but consistently failed when joined together. After reading most of the documentation (which then negates all the effort of using a copilot), the issue was that there was a type discrepancy between two subqueries ... which the co-pilots still "can't see". 

Regarding larger code generation, I am skeptical about security. In a post a few months ago I raised the "A & B & C" type attack, where the code generated is innocuous if you have 1 or 2 out of the 3 parts, but when combined it is a security breach. Since these could be large compound function calls, the surface area for testing is enormous.

Hello all,

Recently, I've been working extensively on building new CSS components. Starting from scratch each time was quite frustrating, so I've developed a [CSS component scaffolder](https://github.com/Liquid-Surf/css-component-generator). This tool generates new components based on templates, currently including:

- Adding a new API endpoint to CSS (from my work on [FedCM](https://github.com/Liquid-Surf/fedcm-demo)).
- Adding new login methods to CSS (from my work on [direct SSO auth](https://github.com/Liquid-Surf/css-direct-sso-auth)).
- A basic "hello world" component that logs to the console (based on the default [hello world](https://github.com/CommunitySolidServer/hello-world-component) example).

Going forward, each time I create a new component, I'll abstract its essential parts and incorporate it as a template. I'm also considering doing this with existing components.

The CSS learning curve can be steep, so I hope this scaffolder will help newcomers get started more easily. Feel free to suggest new template ideas or point me towards components you'd like to see converted into templates!

@room:matrix.org Great news - we (the Practitioners group) have been allotted a position on the ODI Solid Advisory Committe.  This will provide a direct pathway both to learn about what the committee is planning and to provide coordinated feedback to them based on our practical experiences and first-hand knowledge.  We will need to draft a charter with rules for membership and voting to indicate how we will select our representative.  I'll be posting a draft charter soon but would *really* welcome advice on what it should say and how we should operate.  It would be great if we can have a draft charter to present to the group at our next meeting.
content.formatted_body: @room:matrix.org Great news - we (the Practitioners group) have been allotted a position on the ODI Solid Advisory Committe. This will provide a direct pathway both to learn about what the committee is planning and to provide coordinated feedback to them based on our practical experiences and first-hand knowledge. We will need to draft a charter with rules for membership and voting to indicate how we will select our representative. I'll be posting a draft charter soon but would really welcome advice on what it should say and how we should operate. It would be great if we can have a draft charter to present to the group at our next meeting.

mwhaddle: Marc - I watched the datasolids video, and it looks to me the way you are doing it, you are effectively not using Solid at all.  That is, you are using some Solid pod server of some kind behind the internet, but the entire Solid API is not available to any user of the system?  In other words, you could use any backend you want in the installation you demoed and it would function the same and the data of all users is effectively siloed in your app?
content.formatted_body: mwhaddle: Marc - I watched the datasolids video, and it looks to me the way you are doing it, you are effectively not using Solid at all. That is, you are using some Solid pod server of some kind behind the internet, but the entire Solid API is not available to any user of the system? In other words, you could use any backend you want in the installation you demoed and it would function the same and the data of all users is effectively siloed in your app?

content.body: Fred- Our focus is on a use case leveraging Solid principles to enable custody- and therefore control- of patient data in Healthcare/PLS. When we were fleshing out this use case, it became clear that the basic Solid pod model could not provide the security requirements for storing health data. Additionally, we at Datasolids are all risk & security practitioners so we take a brutally practical view in how we build things. Solid is the only framework we know of that enables the utility we are aiming for when it comes to patient control of their data, so we made some changes to the architecture to achieve the security profile needed for the use case. Could any backend work for the installation we demoed? Not for health data, or any other flavor of data deemed sensitive, we've found. User control of data is what we're focused on, and the highest measure of control comes from possession, or custody. We want to provide the most secure option available to achieve that, but also to protect what users hold in their pod. We tend to shy away from religious discussions about being failthful to a certain vision of the spec...we're more interested in real world traction. Given the growing awareness that users have basically no control of their data, and can't trust the incumbent stewards to effectively secure it....users want options, especially patients. We will give them those...

content.body: mwhaddle:  "the basic Solid pod model could not provide the security requirements for storing health data"  why do you think that?
content.formatted_body: mwhaddle: "the basic Solid pod model could not provide the security requirements for storing health data" why do you think that?

content.body: When we started, we did a series of vulnerability assessments on the basic Solid Pod model & had concerns about the results. Given that there is a regulatory framework (HIPAA, PHI) in place for parties that store & exchange patient data, we would have to meet the same requirements as any other health data steward, as our intent is to give the patient technical parity with providers & payors in the ecosystem. This involves a big step-up in governance too, as much of the current principles are written under the guise of the individual not having storage/share capability, especially in healthcare.
One big requirement we identified for this use case was the need for an abstraction layer between the backend & frontend in order to handle the traffic flow & control the security around the Pod.
@mwhaddle:matrix.org were your vulnerability assessments of the Solid Pod model or of CSS?
content.formatted_body: @mwhaddle were your vulnerability assessments of the Solid Pod model or of CSS?

content.body: What vulnerabilities, and when you say "basic Solid Pod" do you mean the open source pod providers?  I'm confident we have military level security beyond what is needed for health with TrinPod's approach, for example.
Other servers will have a different vulnerability profile.

Indeed. One big detail here- we are advancing a use case where Solid principles can make a real impact. Yes, the assessments were done on the basic open source model. At first, we built with NSS in mind, but switched to CSS as NSS isn't maintained as often as CSS. We haven't done a vulnerability assessment of CSS yet.
CSS is in no way an enterprise Solid Server, such as Inrupt or Trinpod, so for sure not the right candidate for your use case.

That's on the roadmap, as this likely will scale to a level where CSS isn't the better choice. At this stage, we are developing the pod user interface & the process/data flows, etc. There will be a need for a true ESS, of course when we reach production.

I would recommend either going for an enterprise server solution, or instead of building a fully incompatible abstraction layer, build another enterprise server solution that uses Solid.  Otherwise, I think you just have a fully siloed system and your users have no way to get their data out or share or read except through your proprietary API - which is no different than any other siloed application out there now?
If you do plan to go with an Enterprise solution eventually, I would ditch the abstraction layer in your prototype as that bypasses all things Solid.
I'm a very big fan of your use case, and think its the perfect candidate for Solid and solving the HIPAA issues by patients and providers controlling their own pods.
I would also go a step further on the xml data you have and translate in the pod to queryable linked data and capture the space-time of it so you can always look at current state vs past

Given the use case, a siloed system is a requirement. An abstraction layer puts a buffer between the patient's pod & the internet. That's a critical detail in the security profile. Our solution also contemplates the storage & sharing of data individually, but also collectively. So, for what we're building here, we're not using Solid to "do" something......we're doing something "using" Solid.
mwhaddle:   That makes no sense, you are just using a different security model to do the same thing as Solid Protocol which is fully secure with enterprise level servers
content.formatted_body: mwhaddle: That makes no sense, you are just using a different security model to do the same thing as Solid Protocol which is fully secure with enterprise level servers

content.body: One additional (& huge) detail is that we must maintain the chain of custody of the health data. This is all about the performance of the security, not the mere presence of it.

You can capture full space-time events and complete history in the pods.  For example, in TrinPod, nothing is ever deleted - space-time is added to.  All events capture input and output state as well as the agent performing the function to make any change (including just read).  So full transparency down to the single triple/state level

"I would also go a step further on the xml data you have and translate in the pod to queryable linked data and capture the space-time of it so you can always look at current state vs past".... indeed. That makes the chain of custody easier to maintain....also provides a much better method to track/audit for HIPAA. One overarching intent is to have the best, most complete & current data under patient control. Provenance is no small part of that.
It is true that it took us many years of development to reach internet/enterprise scale with this approach.
* It is true that it took us many years of development to reach internet/enterprise scale with this approach.

m.new_content.body: It is true that it took us many years of development to reach internet/enterprise scale with this approach.

content.body: Sure it does, when you contemplate what objects are being stored in the pod. If it's pictures & social media, that's one thing. This is health data, so a different beast. Siloed is necessary here, & not going to be a blocker for patient adoption. The big sea change is the custody of the data by the patient...they actually want a siloed system for this, with them holding the keys.

And the providers & payors actually like this approach, as it cleans up myriad process flows on their ends. It's when the notion emerges that the power imbalance has been negated & they no longer have exclusive control of patient data things get interesting....

content.body: mwhaddle: I think my point here is regardless of what you store in the pod, with enterprise servers, its military level secure.  So creating yet another siloed application, which I think is what your abstraction layer would be doing, means that you would be very similar to other siloed approaches without adding in any way to the security you get (maybe diminishing actually) from the Enterprise Solid approach.  An analogy would be pre the web - when there were many "BBS" system (I hosted one on a commodore 64) each of those was separate vs. the web where things are interoperable.  You would effectively have a non-interoperable thing that you would have to sell.  With enterprise Solid, not only do you have security beyond the needs of healthcare, but the future-proof insurance that your users can switch to other providers when needed - no proprietary lock-in.

content.body: Is Enterprise Solid HIPAA compliant?

sorry to intervene - HIPAA / PCI / GDPR are mostly process-focused ... ACL is the only specific tech area (data protection = depends on how you encrypt and transfer / audit trails = shouldn't be stored in the same location / backup&recovery = process)
I'm aware. Would be interested to know of ESS has been subjected to HIPAA evaluation. My intital take is not.
If the issue is process while running the server, both ESS and TrinPod can be self-hosted.

content.body: We should talk to Jesse about this, but my understanding is that the repo (which is under solid/) is overseen by ODI and is therefore the home of a) the data and b) the version of the viewer that will be displayed on solidproject.org, also overseen by ODI.  That viewer is currently mine but the plan is to replace it with one Jesse is writing using LDO.  You are, of course free to create other shapes and viewers for display elsewhere, presumably with links from the solidproject.org one.  Ieben at Ghent is working on re-doing the forms and once those are done, those will also live in the solid/ repo as part of the live solidproject.org catalog.

Well, technically, all the proxies' (RDP for internal rights delegation, and DPP for data provisioning chains) APIs are basically Solid APIs. They expect Solid-OIDC and manage access to their API using WAC. So, I'd argue that these are Solid Protocol compliant :) From the outside, they look like any Solid Pod, except that they do not just serve data but do some additional logic as well.

content.body:
Well, I do not recall the exact paragraphs but the general requirements as communicated by our partners were along the lines of:

- relationship between SME and TAO must not be revealed (unless SME chooses to)
- relationship between employee and organisation should not be revealed (if not necessary (it is not necessary) or unless the employee chooses to)
- tracing of activities, there must be documentation at the organisation that shows who was granted access by whom when and when did access occur, when were actions triggered by the employee to be then executed on behalf of the company, were they actually executed or declined to be executed, ... (and so on)
- and some more, which I do not recall of the top of my head but should (TM) be documented in the papers.

Also, keep in mind, that we wanted to build on the decentralised nature of the Web - not relying on a central facilitator (even though DATEV might be in / take such a role).
From the outside of a company (e.g. consider the first image, "Figure 2", posted by pavlik above) only Solid-compliant APIs are exposed / necessary. To join such an ecosystem, the internal components (RDP, DPP, ...) are not strictly required. Organisations can choose to solve the corresponding problems differently. Only a Solid-compliant API - e.g. the Pod (or DPP) - needs to be exposed.

I'd be interested in what you think would pose a simple solution.

From the outside of a company (e.g. consider the first image, "Figure 2", posted by pavlik above) only Solid-compliant APIs are exposed / necessary. To join such an ecosystem, the internal components (RDP, DPP, ...) are not strictly required. Organisations can choose to solve the corresponding problems differently. Only a Solid-compliant API - e.g. the Pod (or DPP) - needs to be exposed.

I'd be interested in what you think would pose a simple solution.

content.body: I am confused by the line "frontend - backend" ... if "backend" means internal, then I have no idea how do peers engage ...

Also based on the thread about delegation, yesterday I created an example in ODRL for the "Agent" delegation scenario - most people are practically worried about AI Agents so that's the theme, but it should be "any" agent. And I am only covering the authorisation/entitlements, and I am not interested in the identity/authentication portion (that's someone else's problem). https://github.com/w3c/odrl/issues/112

No, backend does not necessarily mean internal / not exposed. It just means that these components are server-side components while the frontend are browser-based apps (we just used SPAs for simplicity in the project.). How exactly the backend components are configured to be exposed is open to configuration, we basically chose the let the DPP wrap the Pod, exposing the usual Solid API. RDP could e.g. only accept HTTP requests from organisational IP addresses. (In our project, it is also exposed as it is a usual Solid API and access was only granted to the corresponding organisation's employees) - but again these things can be solved differently - as long as there is a Solid compliant API, and to be fair, a description what container expects what data, similar to SAI.

Sleepy.bike Community Solid Pod has been down since January. I don't control the domain and no longer have github access to update the instance. I turned the infrastructure off in January after 5 months notice. The app hosted by github pages remains. The state is very unfortunate.

There are other instances (tired.bike, folks.solidcouch.org) that I maintain, feel free to try them (your sleepy.bike profile data should be compatible); but I wouldn't recommend listing them at the moment as it's a contentious topic.

content.body: Yes, its meant to be a broad category perhaps a better name is needed
I'll need to manually add your records but they should be visible later today.

Also, I have some comments on the fields to put for papers, as the current ones don't feel natural when inputting. In particular, "technical keywords" is usually non-existent for a paper, as they are generally not a single system (or, app) for end users. Also it would be useful to rename "landing page" to be clearer about either a) a link to the paper's record page (e.g. publisher's, or arxiv); b) a link to paper's companion website / description page / code repository (if any).

I didn't know about Ruben's work.  Thanks! :-)  I wrote an HDT reader in Javascript way back then, using it as an experimental streaming protocol over WebSockets.  I found it a bit more efficient than compressed n-triples as I could directly read the HDT payload on the client.  Binary RDF is a area of interest of mine.  Happy to talk shop on it anytime :D
I would imagine so when the BitmapTriples form is used as indexes are created to facilitate fast searching.  I wonder if they tried the TriplesList version which would work better for streaming.

On the social query:

- how do you protect from DDos ?
- What is I want "partial" trust (e.g. "I want to answer questions about jobs, but not about dating?")
content.formatted_body:
On the social query:

  • how do you protect from DDos ?
  • What is I want "partial" trust (e.g. "I want to answer questions about jobs, but not about dating?")

content.body: actually a 3rd: how do you protect from "infinite loops" and "hammering Kevin Bacon" (apparently after 6 degrees, everyone is connected to Kevin)

> <@josh-cornejo:matrix.org> actually a 3rd: how do you protect from "infinite loops" and "hammering Kevin Bacon" (apparently after 6 degrees, everyone is connected to Kevin)

both cases are answered with a simple mechanism: each participant in a social query keeps track of the unique identifier of that query, and will not answer twice to it.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @josh-cornejo:matrix.org
actually a 3rd: how do you protect from "infinite loops" and "hammering Kevin Bacon" (apparently after 6 degrees, everyone is connected to Kevin)
both cases are answered with a simple mechanism: each participant in a social query keeps track of the unique identifier of that query, and will not answer twice to it.

content.body: but that doesn't stop the possibility of network overflow and the message reaching that 'layer' ?
There's no way Kevin Bacon's phone will handle 'discards'
(or maybe the phone never gets it, but the network will overflow?)

> <@josh-cornejo:matrix.org> On the social query:
> 
> - how do you protect from DDos ?
> - What is I want "partial" trust (e.g. "I want to answer questions about jobs, but not about dating?")

DDOS : you can only send query requests to the inbox of someone you know.
the inbox has a random ID of 32 bytes.

and only registered users can contact their home broker to do so.

the only attack surface is the login mechanism on the broker. it concerns all API calls, not only social queries.
it will be defended by classical means ( fail2ban ). and also with https://github.com/mCaptcha/mCaptcha

In reply to @josh-cornejo:matrix.org

the phone or device will not get any spam message as the inbox IF is unknowable to the attacker

> - What is I want "partial" trust (e.g. "I want to answer questions about jobs, but not about dating?")

partial trust is handled easily with access control. when user receives a social query that doesnt have permission yet for remote user to use the needed data, then a notification asks for such permission, that can be restricted by resource class and storage location

content.body: I see that the potential DDoS could be at network level, not app level (all my 300 contacts would send me a message ... and to all people in their contact list, but we will "forward" only once ... although not sure how i determine that I don't need to send it back to everyone that sent it to me as now I need to keep track of who from the 300 sent it, and which didn't?)
we only receive requests from trusted users who are in our contact list
Yes
I get that
we forward to everyone we know, but they might not answer to us, if tgey already answered the same query via someone else in the social network
But in simple terms: i have 3 friends ... i get 2 messages and should only forward to the 1 person that didn't send it to me, so the app needs to track who sent it?

i never forward to the users who sent me a request. but in the case you mention, if we call them A B and C, when i receive the request from A i forward to B and C. when B receives it, it doesn't send it back to me. if you are talking about a race condition where B sends the same request to me cincurrently wirh A, then it could be that i send the message to A and B. they will only answer it once, so all is good

* i never forward to the users who sent me a request. but in the case you mention, if we call them A B and C, when i receive the request from A i forward to B and C. when B receives it, it doesn't send it back to me. if you are talking about a race condition where B sends the same request to me cincurrently wirh A, then it could be that i send the message to A and B. they will only answer it once, so all is good

content.body: once across all the social network.

I think it is more of a potential overflow if it is not concurrent (e.g. A sends the message at 10am / B at 11 am ...) ... I suppose you could use ULID's for time sequencing and maybe TTL are included (e.g. 30 min)

the case you mention is the concurrent case. everything is asynchronous, we do not take into account timing.
A and B sends me the same request, then i will only answer to the first one

content.body: and will forward it to everyone except the one i just received it from
so when i receive it from A, i will forward to B. and 1 hour later, when i receive it from B, i will not forward it to anyone, because i already did that.
B must have been offline, and will not process the request i send it. when B gets online again, it will discard my request because it surely already processed it

content.body: Thanks Jeff Zucker (he/him) !  I don't know that I need to present particularly, although I'm happy to if people are interested related to any specific use case.  But I'll probably need to lurk a bit to get a feel for the work and the process.  And I haven't worked in Solid, although I've followed elf-pavlik (elf Pavlik) along that journey from a distance for awhile, and probably know a couple other people here.  I came in because someone ran into this project https://solid.github.io/erp/, and noticed the resonance with Valueflows, and pinged Pavlik and Michiel de Jong (Ponder Source) in the Valueflows channel.  Pavlik put a *lot* of work into Valueflows in the early years.  Both ERP and Food were important use case inputs to Valueflows.  And a few years ago, we did some data mapping with DFC.  Anyhow, I'd be interested in hearing what Tom Byrd has to say on Sept 18.  And I'm happy to be here and get more acquainted!

Welcome Jon!  We encourage everyone to participate to the extent they want to and that includes lurking.  We do invite everyone to introduce themselves and their interests/projects at meetings but "Hi I'm Jon" is totally fine if that's all you want to share at the time.  @lynnfoster:matrix.org please take your time in acclimating to the group but also be aware that when we say "present at a meeting" we aren't necessarily talking about any kind of formal presentation.  The purpose of our group is to share knowledge with each other, to learn about and help each other with our projects.  So some presentations are full demos of working projects and some are just a description of the project and a brainstorming session about similar projects or particular issues the project faces.

content.body: @lynnfoster:matrix.org I have tentatively chosen our 18 September meeting to have a session on food scarcity, food distribution, and short supply chains.  I am inviting Maxime Lecoq from the Data Food Consortium, and Tom Byrd from the Baltimore Food Project to present and hereby invite you to either present or simply attend if you prefer.  Does that date work for you?  If not, does the first or third Thursday in October work for you?
content.formatted_body: @lynnfoster I have tentatively chosen our 18 September meeting to have a session on food scarcity, food distribution, and short supply chains. I am inviting Maxime Lecoq from the Data Food Consortium, and Tom Byrd from the Baltimore Food Project to present and hereby invite you to either present or simply attend if you prefer. Does that date work for you? If not, does the first or third Thursday in October work for you?

content.body: I am almost positive Sept 18 works. I'll know for sure later in August, but I think it's good to go ahead with it.  I can present or listen.  If I present, I could be a shorter add-on to the others, since Valueflows isn't specific to food.  Although I can demo a short supply chain.
As I understand it, projects dealing with food scarcity often involve short supply chain whether that applies to local farm produce or food banks redistributing food.
content.formatted_body: As I understand it, projects dealing with food scarcity often involve short supply chain whether that applies to local farm produce or food banks redistributing food.

content.body: That makes sense.  And we could probably all benefit from a short supply chain for food, local is good for fresh food. :)
Yes, especially in inner-city areas where grocery options are limited and are not a prime location for  organic/health food stores serving more privileged areas.
content.formatted_body: Yes, especially in inner-city areas where grocery options are limited and are not a prime location for organic/health food stores serving more privileged areas.

content.body: !help reminder

**Reminders**

Create an optionally recurring reminder that notifies the reminder creator:

```
!remindme|remind|r [every <recurring time>;] <start time>; <reminder text>
```

Create an optionally recurring reminder that notifies the whole room.
(Note that the bot will need appropriate permissions to mention
the room):

```
!remindroom|rr [every <recurring time>;] <start time>; <reminder text>
```

List all active reminders for a room:

```
!listreminders|list|lr|l
```

Cancel a reminder:

```
!cancelreminder|cancel|cr|c <reminder text>
```

**Alarms**

Create a reminder that will repeatedly sound every 5m after its usual
fire time. Otherwise, the syntax is the same as a reminder:

```
!alarmme|alarm|a [every <recurring time>;] <start time>; <reminder text>
```

or for notifying the whole room:

```
!alarmroom|ar [every <recurring time>;] <start time>; <reminder text>
```

Once firing, an alarm can be silenced with:

```
!silence|s [<reminder text>]
```

**Cron-tab Syntax**

If you need more complicated recurring reminders, you can make use of
cron-tab syntax:

```
!remindme|remind|r cron <min> <hour> <day of month> <month> <day of week>; <reminder text>
```

This syntax is supported by any `!remind...` or `!alarm...` command above.

content.body: Had what we call a "Red Hack Day" today. Scraped together a loose demo that at least included login and retrieval of user profile data. A lot of learning on my part, but also proof to me of how great the potential for Solid is. Biggest gripe is the same as for most of my undertakings lately: Node has mostly maimed native development for the browser. The other thing that was hard is finding good/current documentation that doesn't 404 frequently. The Inrupt content was a frequent letdown in both regards  https://github.com/ewingson/solid-info was a godsend though to get over the biggest bumps.

content.body: Thought this group might be a good one to have thoughts or experience that I could pass along for my ongoing saga of trying to convince/sell folks internally on using Solid. Last week I sent an impassioned recommendation to our senior leadership to read "This is for Everyone", and to consider Solid. Today an assortment of people (no senior leadership) had a meeting with a group that is leveraging Snowflake (Dataverse?) as an aggregator for user data from a variety of sources (training, Adobe, events, etc.). The issue I'm running up against is that we've already got auth using Keycloak or IBM Verify, and now this snowflake piece could apparently handle CRUD operations. How do I get people over what seems like the insurmountable hurdle of wanting to give users their data sovereignty when faced with other solutions that, on the surface, appear to achieve the same functionality? I'm not a good salesperson.

Since you mentioned Keycloak, there was an ongoing work for adding Solid-OIDC support: https://github.com/CarrettiPro/keycloak-solid. I used to have it listed in Solid Efforts. I will need to add it back.
In general, I would be cautious to always be clear that Solid is still a moving target. Currently, it is based on a set of Solid CG drafts, some providing alternatives to one another, and various work happening outside of the CG, which is also part of the broader Solid Ecosystem. The first cornerstone of solid will be the W3C LWS spec, which will be finalized in the best case a year from now. I would expect that the WG charter may need to be extended, and it may take even longer.    Meanwhile, implementation feedback is fundamental, so if people are in a position to aim for the long run and have the capacity to adjust to inevitable changes, then I would say try to help with making Solid happen. Personally, I see it as an alpha test period, where everyone needs to know that things are still work in progress, and while there is certain extra effort, it's also an opportunity to contribute to the final result in a meaningful way.

content.formatted_body:
Folks, I will not be able to join meeting on Thursday, I would still like to share something cool I have been playing with a little bit in last two days. It is a tool for architecture diagrams, especially architecture as code. Some of you may remember videos I made for TPAC a while ago https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLXBho_YohPB3SreXojlJLa9MaprXRDhdR
It was done with prioprietary web app called IcePanel. Now I tried an open source alternative which is also amazing! https://likec4.dev/
They have playground but share link doesn't work for me, if you want to see early draft of architecture for my next generation setup of Solid (it will take some time to write missing code and fully deploy it), you can just paste this snippet in the Like4C playground

specification {
  element system
  element container
  element component
}

model {
  system h4p {
    container Auth 'Auth' 'auth.h4p.net' {
      style {
        shape rectangle
        color red
      }
      component OIDC 'Solid-OIDC' 'CSS'
      component SAI 'SAI Agent' 'sai-js'
      component FedCM 'FedCM IdP' 'liquid.surf'
      component SAIStore 'SAI Store' 'CSS' 'Registry Set' {
        style {
          shape storage
          color sky
          icon http://www.w3.org/RDF/icons/rdf_flyer.64
        }
        component AuthorizationRegistry 'Authorization Registry' {
          style {
            color red
          }
        }
        component AgentRegistry 'Agent Registry' {
          style {
            shape person
            color green
          }
        }
        component RoleRegistry 'Role Registry' {
          style {
            shape person
            color green
          }
        }
        component ACPPolicyEngine 'ACP Policy Engine' {
          style {
            color red
          }
        }

      }
    }
    container WWW 'WWW' 'www.h4p.net' {
      style {
        shape browser
        color indigo
        icon https://lit.dev/images/logo.svg
      }
    }
    container Data 'Data' '*.data.h4p.net' {
      style {
        shape storage
        color sky
      }
      component DataRegistry 'Data Registry' {
        style {
          color sky
        }
      }
      component SaiPolicyEngine 'SAI Policy Engine' {
        style {
          color red
        }
      }
    }
    container WebID 'WebID' '*.h4p.net & id.h4p.net' {
      style {
        shape person
        color green
      }
    }
    container Account 'Account' 'account.h4p.net' {
      style {
        shape browser
        color amber
        icon tech:vue
      }
      component AuthScreen 'Authorization Screen' {
        style {
          color: red
        }
        this -> Auth
      }
      component CredentialManagement 'Credential Management' {
        style {
          color: red
        }
        this -> Auth
      }
      component SocialGraph 'Social Graph' {
        style {
          shape person
          color: green
        }
        this -> Auth
      }
      component PodManagement 'Pod Management' {
        style {
          color sky
        }
        this -> Data
      }
      component WebIDManagement 'WebID Management' {
        style {
          color green
        }
        this -> WebID
      }
    }
  }

  Account -> Auth
  WWW -> Data
  Data -> Auth
  Auth -> WebID
  Data -> WebID
}

views {
  view index {
    title 'Landscape'
    include h4p
    include h4p.*
  }
  view auth of Auth {
    include Auth
    include Auth.*
  }
  view data of Data {
    include Data
    include Data.*
  }
  view saistore of SAIStore {
    include SAIStore
    include SAIStore.*
  }
  view account of Account {
    include Account
    include Account.*
    include Data
    include WebID
    exclude Data -> WebID
    include Auth
    exclude Data -> Auth
    exclude Auth -> WebID
  }
}

content.body:
> I see it as an alpha test period

I think that statement, while perhaps true when looking solely at the specs, is completely misleading when it comes to user apps.  There are a number of apps which are either in production or are in beta or MVP phase.  It is perfectly feasable to make useful apps in the current state of affairs.  Will those apps need to be revised as the specs come into place, yes proabably.  But that does not meant that they can not perform the functions they were intended  for or be useful to people. This room and group are for people who are building those apps.  Please restrict your nay-saying to the specification channel which is what your critique applies to.  Yes, there are hurdles and things will change but that does not mean that nothing works or that users should be discouraged (as you are attempting to do).  I find it very counter-productive to meet new users with the kind of negativity you are displaying.  That is the way to scare off new users, not how to onboard them.

content.body: The question of adoption is really important and is definitely one that other practitioners are facing and that is an ongoing topic of discussion in our meetings.  This Thursday at 15:00 UTC we will be having a meeting to bring up general topics related to putting Solid into practice.  I invite you to come an open a discussion on the issue you raise and I'm sure others will be interested. The Open Data Institute (ODI), which provides stewardship for Solid is committed to working on issues of adoption so perhaps a discussion with the Solid lead for ODI @jeswr would help you.

content.body: Yeah, my view is proably on a gloomy side, mostly due to looking at things from perspective of fully open and interoperable ecosystem. If one wants to take step towards a semi-silo, where they have much more central control, than I can see that alredy much more can be done. I think we may need something in lines of [Richardson Maturity Model](https://martinfowler.com/articles/richardsonMaturityModel.html) which would help people to gradually adopt things, and possibly on specs writing side set priorities on lower levels.

If one wants to take step towards a semi-silo, where they have much more central control, than I can see that alredy much more can be done. I think we may need something in lines of [Richardson Maturity Model](https://martinfowler.com/articles/richardsonMaturityModel.html) which would help people to gradually adopt things, and possibly on specs writing side set priorities on lower levels.

content.body: The issue of ODI's support for ESS and community.net will definitely be a topic in the Practitioners.  Personally I feel that is better in a discussion format than a survey.   The question of how Solid handles login and security is an architectural question and therefore much more suited to the CG.  Practitioners tries to be bottom up - we start with a social issue or end-user need and work from there to practical ways those can be solved with Solid or other technologies.  Your top-down  approach - here's a technology/architecture question, how do we solve it is quite appropriate for the CG but unless one of our member projects is running into issues that they want addressed related to it, our discussions are focused on practice not theory, on things that exist or are being built today and can be used today to accomplish what our members are seeking to accomplish.  The Practitioners is meant to support people building products and services, not to discuss theories of how security should be handled which is much more appropriate for the CG.  If those topics come up in relation to a Practitioner project we'll certainly pass questions and suggestions to the CG, but I personally don't feel it is appropriate for the CG to raise those issues rather letting Practitioners decide for themselves what topics they want to discuss.

The question of how Solid handles login and security is an architectural question and therefore much more suited to the CG. Practitioners tries to be bottom up - we start with a social issue or end-user need and work from there to practical ways those can be solved with Solid or other technologies. Your top-down approach - here's a technology/architecture question, how do we solve it is quite appropriate for the CG but unless one of our member projects is running into issues that they want addressed related to it, our discussions are focused on practice not theory, on things that exist or are being built today and can be used today to accomplish what our members are seeking to accomplish. The Practitioners is meant to support people building products and services, not to discuss theories of how security should be handled which is much more appropriate for the CG. If those topics come up in relation to a Practitioner project we'll certainly pass questions and suggestions to the CG, but I personally don't feel it is appropriate for the CG to raise those issues rather letting Practitioners decide for themselves what topics they want to discuss.

I installed Solid when it first emerged, but have been sidetracked since then.  I'm thinking it's time to revisit this ecosystem

So was talking with Solid contributor Jackson Morgan, and he told me the name is changing. I don't remember the new name he said would replace it, but I do remember not liking it. Anyone here know the new name?
Michael Munson: Maybe [Linked Web Storage](http://w3.org/groups/wg/lws/)?
content.formatted_body: Michael Munson: Maybe Linked Web Storage?

content.body: I think that's it. Thanks.

I see that as a name for the tech, not a brand for the solution. Like, "open source software" is the type of thing and "Linux" is a specific open-source product. In this case, "Linked Wed Storage" is the type of thing, and Solid is a specific "LWS" solution.
